The language dominance among self-identified Hispanics shifts across generations, as shown in [this image](image1) (Language Dominance Among Self-Identified Hispanics and Non-Hispanics). For foreign-born Hispanics, 61% are Spanish dominant, 32% are bilingual, and only 7% are English dominant. Moreover, connections to the Hispanic heritage decrease as the immigrant roots become more distant (image2 - Connection to Hispanic Heritage Across Generations). 82% of foreign-born self-identified Hispanics feel very or somewhat connected, compared to 69% of second-generation Hispanics, and a diminishing 44% of third or higher generation Hispanics. The perception of connection to Hispanic heritage varies significantly across different generations of self-identified Hispanics. Foreign-born Hispanics feel the most connected to their heritage, with 82% feeling very or somewhat connected. This percentage drops to 69% for second-generation Hispanics and further decreases to 44% for third or higher generation Hispanics [2][image2]. 

When it comes to the perceived advantages of being Hispanic, there is also a generational divide. 52% of second-generation Hispanics believe their Hispanic background has been an advantage in their lives, compared to 28% of immigrant Hispanics and 24% of third or higher generation Hispanics [11].

However, among self-identified non-Hispanics, only 34% feel very or somewhat connected to their Hispanic heritage, and only 11% perceive it as an advantage [8][image2][image6].

In conclusion, while there is a strong connection to Hispanic heritage and positive perceptions of its advantages among first and second-generation Hispanics, these feelings decrease among higher generation self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics.

When examining the perceptions of racial identity among different generations of self-identified Hispanics in the U.S., one can observe notable differences. According to [image2](![69% of self-identified Hispanics identify as Hispanic or Latino, while this drops to 46% among third or higher generation Hispanics](image2)), the perception of being Hispanic or Latino decreases as the generations pass, replaced by a higher tendency to identify as white. This shift in racial identity perception is particularly evident when comparing foreign-born Hispanics to third or higher generation Hispanics.

The impact of Hispanic heritage also varies across generations, as shown in [image6](![34% of self-identified Hispanics overall consider their Hispanic heritage as an advantage, this percentage increasing to 52% among the second generation](image6)). When looking at [image10](![Hispanic heritage has the greatest impact on the lives of second-generation Hispanics, with 52% considering it an advantage](image10)), the positive impact of Hispanic heritage is strongest for the second generation, whereas it is perceived as less influential for immigrants and third or higher generation Hispanics.

In summary, perceptions of racial identity and the impact of Hispanic heritage differ significantly among generations of self-identified Hispanics in the U.S., with a clear trend of decreased identification as Hispanic or Latino and a higher identification as white as the generations pass. Furthermore, the positive impact of Hispanic heritage appears to be strongest for the second generation.

The perception of discrimination and racial identification among Hispanics varies across different generations. [According to a Pew Research Center study](https://www.pewresearch.org/hispanic/2016/04/05/hispanic-identity-fades-across-generations-as-immigrant-connections-fall-away/), higher generations of adults with Hispanic ancestry experience less frequent discrimination related to their Hispanic background. However, a significant portion of self-identified Hispanics ($39\%$) still report feeling discriminated against due to their Hispanic or Latino background.

When comparing [racial identification](image3), later generations of self-identified Hispanics increasingly identify as White. Among foreign-born Hispanics, $78\%$ identify as Hispanic or Latino, but this share drops to $46\%$ for third or higher generation Hispanics. Conversely, the share identifying as White increases from $11\%$ for foreign-born Hispanics to $25\%$ for third or higher generation Hispanics.

Furthermore, [connections to Hispanic heritage](image4) diminish over generations, as only $44\%$ of third or higher generation Hispanics feel connected, compared to $82\%$ of foreign-born Hispanics. Self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry also show lower levels of connection, with $65\%$ feeling not very or not connected at all.

Regarding perceptions of discrimination (image1), immigrant Latinos ($41\%$) and second-generation Hispanics ($41\%$) are more likely to believe that all or most people share similar views about those from their background compared to third or higher generation Hispanics ($30\%$). Self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry report the lowest levels of shared views at $17\%$.

In conclusion, generational differences significantly impact the perception of discrimination and racial identification among Hispanics, with later generations increasingly identifying as White and reporting lower levels of connection to their Hispanic heritage.

The use of the term "Hispanic" varies widely across different generations of immigrants, with each group having unique experiences that influence their identity [1]. This is also reflected in how much Hispanics feel a common identity with other Americans. While 50% consider themselves a typical American, 44% believe they are very different [2]. This generational divide is significant; for instance, 36% of immigrant Hispanics consider themselves typical Americans, compared to 73% of third or higher generation Hispanics [8].

Interestingly, when it comes to the link between Latino identity and speaking Spanish, 71% of Latino adults believe speaking Spanish is not required to be considered Latino [3]. This sentiment is strong among all generations: 58% of immigrant Latinos, 84% of second-generation Latinos, and 92% of third or higher generation Latinos agree [4].

In terms of self-identification, the data suggests that being foreign-born increases the likelihood of often self-identifying as Hispanic (57%) compared to second (50%) and third or higher generation individuals (33) [2]. However, for non-Hispanics, the majority (53%) never identify as Hispanic [2]. Different reasons contribute to not identifying as Hispanic, including mixed background, no contact with Hispanic relatives, not speaking Spanish, identifying with another race, or being born in the U.S. [3].

Regarding language use, more than 90% of third or higher generation Hispanics do not speak Spanish [4]. Connections with ancestral national origins also decline as immigrant roots become more distant [9]. The share of immigrants who feel very or somewhat connected with their country of origin is 82%, compared to 69% for second-generation Hispanics, and only 44% for third or higher generation Hispanics [9]. In contrast, the share of third or higher generation Latinos who most often call themselves American is 56%, reflecting their strong ties to their U.S. national identity [7].

In conclusion, generational differences among Hispanics significantly impact self-identification preferences and language use. With each subsequent generation, the tendency to self-identify as Hispanic decreases, the ties to U.S. national identity increase, and the likelihood of speaking Spanish significantly drops.

The USA has the highest energy consumption per capita at 8080 kg oil equivalent, while China has a much lower consumption of 597 kg oil equivalent per capita. Germany's energy consumption per capita is 4017 kg oil equivalent. This difference in energy consumption is partly due to the higher number of motor vehicles per 1,000 people in the USA (804) compared to China (186) and Germany (666) [6], [3]. 

In terms of CO2 emissions, the USA has a significant share of global motor vehicle demand and a high number of motor vehicles per 1,000 people, contributing to its higher emissions [3]. On the other hand, China has a large share in global demand but a lower number of motor vehicles per 1,000 people [3]. 

![High CO2 emissions and motor vehicle ownership in the USA](image3)

These differences in energy consumption and motor vehicle ownership imply that the USA has a larger environmental impact due to higher CO2 emissions per capita. China and Germany, despite having large economies and significant motor vehicle demand, have lower energy consumption and CO2 emissions per capita due to lower motor vehicle ownership rates [6]. 

It is also important to note that the transportation sector accounts for 30.0% of CO2 emissions in industrialized economies and about 20.0% worldwide [12]. Therefore, reducing motor vehicle ownership and energy consumption in the transportation sector could significantly decrease CO2 emissions and mitigate environmental impacts.

In conclusion, the USA has higher CO2 emissions per capita and motor vehicle ownership compared to China and Germany, implying a larger environmental impact in the transportation sector.

When comparing [VC performance in Europe to that in the USA](https://i.imgur.com/wX5pPJg.png), several key factors come into play, particularly [in terms of investment multiples and exit values](https://i.imgur.com/M0nR6su.png).

European VC has been demonstrating strong fundamentals and higher capital efficiency compared to the US, leading to [outperformance based on an over-proportional share in successful exits](https://i.imgur.com/NnSdVUf.png) in the region. This performance is not limited to just a few exits; [European VC has been driving the best exit multiples globally](https://i.imgur.com/xhx5INh.png).

While the average exit values in Europe are approximately 25% smaller, other factors compensate for this discrepancy. [Europe's lower entry valuations](https://i.imgur.com/HFvko6v.png), coupled with higher capital efficiency (roughly 70% higher than in the US), make up for the difference in exit values. This efficiency can be attributed to the scarcity of VC money in Europe, where the limited number of investors are more selective, leading to higher yields in the form of successful exits.

As a result, [Europe has a higher median multiple of cash invested and a greater percentage of investments reaching a multiple of 5 or more compared to the USA](https://i.imgur.com/0LJjGIM.png). This trend is visually represented by the European circle (median multiple of 7.2) being larger than the US circle (median multiple of 4.5).

In summary, even though average exit values in Europe are smaller, the region's venture capital performance is comparable to or even surpasses that of the US, as shown by higher investment multiples and a greater percentage of successful exits achieving a multiple of 5 or more.

When it comes to in-store Wi-Fi, there are several prominent purposes and benefits to consider. One key application is the integration of Wi-Fi data into various systems like POS (Point of Sale), CRM (Customer Relationship Management), and loyalty programs [2][8][11]. By doing so, businesses can gain valuable insights into customer behavior, preferences, and patterns, which can be used to enhance customer experiences and drive sales [3][6][10].

Some of the main reasons customers use in-store Wi-Fi include gathering demographic information, taking advantage of sales conversions, checking the times of use, utilizing social media conversions, understanding time in-store, increasing loyalty/repeat visits, locating hot spots, and analyzing what devices other customers use [2]. The duration of guest Wi-Fi sessions and traffic counting are also important aspects of Wi-Fi utilization [2].

Across various sectors, the prevalence of in-store Wi-Fi usage varies. In the General Merchandise & Specialty sector, both company and customer Wi-Fi access is utilized by 51% of businesses, while 46% use it only for company purposes and 3% provide Wi-Fi access only for customers [4]. In the Food, Drug, Conv, Mass segment, 22% of businesses offer both company and customer Wi-Fi access, while 78% use it only for company purposes, and there is no customer Wi-Fi-only usage [4]. Among Hospitality businesses, 85% offer both company and customer Wi-Fi access, 8% use it only for company purposes, and 8% offer Wi-Fi access only for customers [4].

In conclusion, here's how different sectors use in-store Wi-Fi:
- 51% of General Merchandise & Specialty businesses offer both company and customer Wi-Fi access.
- 22% of Food, Drug, Conv, Mass businesses offer both company and customer Wi-Fi access.
- 85% of Hospitality businesses offer both company and customer Wi-Fi access.

![Different sectors' Wi-Fi usage distribution](image4)

Different sectors utilize in-store Wi-Fi in various ways to engage with customers and promote their businesses. For instance, Hospitality sector makes extensive use of both company Wi-Fi and customer Wi-Fi access, with 85% of their Wi-Fi access falling under this category [image4]. This shows a significant focus on customer engagement in this sector through Wi-Fi.

General Merchandise & Specialty sector also demonstrates a considerable use of both company and customer Wi-Fi access, with 51% of their Wi-Fi access falling under this category [image4]. This suggests that they too are actively engaging customers through Wi-Fi.

On the other hand, the Food, Drug, Conv, Mass sector seems to focus more on company Wi-Fi access, with 78% of their Wi-Fi access being used only for company purposes [image4]. This could imply that this sector is less focused on customer engagement through Wi-Fi.

As for the main analytics used by stores to assess Wi-Fi usage, the most common ones include demographics, sales conversion by Wi-Fi, times of use, social media conversions, time in store, loyalty/repeat visits to store, hot spots in store, what devices customers use, guest Wi-Fi session duration, and traffic counting [image6].

In conclusion, the Hospitality and General Merchandise & Specialty sectors seem to use in-store Wi-Fi more for customer engagement, while the Food, Drug, Conv, Mass sector focuses more on company use. The main analytics used to assess Wi-Fi usage include demographics, sales conversion, and social media conversions, among others.

![Hospitality and General Merchandise & Specialty sectors make extensive use of both company and customer Wi-Fi access, while Food, Drug, Conv, Mass sector focuses more on company Wi-Fi access](image4)

![The main analytics used by stores to assess Wi-Fi usage include demographics, sales conversion by Wi-Fi, times of use, social media conversions, time in store, loyalty/repeat visits to store, hot spots in store, what devices customers use, guest Wi-Fi session duration, and traffic counting](image6)

The impact of customer and employee Wi-Fi on loyalty and sales varies significantly across different sectors.

For employee Wi-Fi, the perception of its impact on customer loyalty and sales is highest in the general merchandise sector, with 53% of respondents believing it increases customer loyalty and a corresponding 4.3% increase in sales [2](image2). The hospitality sector also shows a substantial impact, with 61% of respondents indicating an increase in customer loyalty and a 2.5% sales increase [2](image2). However, the food, drug, convenience, and mass (FDCM) segment has the lowest perception of Wi-Fi's impact on loyalty (11%) and a relatively small sales increase of 0.6% [2](image2).

On the other hand, when it comes to customer Wi-Fi, the hospitality sector leads with 61% of respondents saying it impacts customer loyalty and a 2.7% sales increase [6](image6). General merchandise follows with 22% indicating an impact on loyalty and a 2.2% sales increase [6](image6). The FDCM segment has zero respondents perceiving an impact on customer loyalty, and a minimal 0.3% increase in sales [6](image6).

In addition, the average sales increase and EBITA percentage improvements for each sector give further insight into the impact of Wi-Fi on sales and profits [5](image5). For instance, the general merchandise sector has an overall sales increase of 6.5% and an impressive EBITA increase of 32.1% after adding WiFi for customers and associates [5](image5).

Finally, we can observe the average sales and increase in sales from adding WiFi for customers and associates across different sectors as follows [7](image7):

- General Merchandise (Avg. Sales: $850M, Avg. Sales Increase: $55.2M)
- Food/Drug/Conv/Mass (Avg. Sales: $8,000M, Avg. Sales Increase: $72.0M)
- Hospitality (Avg. Sales: $1,100M, Avg. Sales Increase: $57.2M)

In summary, the impact of customer and employee Wi-Fi on loyalty and sales significantly varies across different sectors. While the general merchandise and hospitality sectors exhibit considerable positive impacts, the FDCM segment generally shows a minor increase in loyalty and sales related to Wi-Fi access.

- **Food, Drug, Convenience, Mass (FDCM)** has the least perceived impact, as only 11% of respondents observe an influence on customer loyalty, resulting in a mere 0.6% sales increase.

These statistics reflect the varying degrees to which different industries perceive employee access to Wi-Fi as a factor in enhancing customer loyalty and subsequently increasing sales.

The growth in digital media and e-commerce has significantly impacted the landscape for digital advertising and online sales between 2014 and 2018. We can see this impact through the lens of several aspects, including the increasing digital payments penetration, the rise of e-commerce platforms, and the shift in advertising spends.

Firstly, the shift towards electronic payment methods in online retail has been substantial. [Image1](image1 - "By 2016, Cash on Delivery is projected to decrease to 50%, as other electronic payment methods, such as debit cards, net banking, EMI, and 3rd party wallets increase.") shows a clear trend of increasing adoption for various electronic payment methods during this period, with a significant decrease in the Cash on Delivery (COD) method from 60% in 2013 to a projected 50% in 2016. This shift highlights the growing trust of Indian consumers in electronic transactions and is indicative of a positive change in the digital commerce landscape.

Secondly, [image4](image4 - "A visual representation of the growth in smartphone users, with 120 million users in 2014 and 380 million users in 2016.") demonstrates the rapid growth of smartphone users in India between 2014 and 2016—a surge from 120 million users to 380 million users. This massive increase in smartphone users has created a fertile ground for e-commerce platforms, making it easier for customers to access and make purchases online.

Moreover, the evolution of e-commerce, as shown in [image3](image3 - "A hockey stick diagram depicting the expansion of e-commerce, highlighting multiple growth phases and elements.")—from inventory-led marketplaces to acquisitions and the addition of various product categories like furniture, jewelry, and homes—suggests that e-commerce players have been proactive in expanding their offerings and infrastructure to cater to the increasing demand.

Lastly, in terms of digital advertising, as shown in [image2](image2 - "A Facebook profile of a politician, featuring social media following data and a graph of user numbers from 110 million in 2014 to 175 million in 2016.") and [image5](image5 - "Table comparing the values of different media categories, including Digital, from 2012 to 2016."), digital has experienced the fastest growth compared to traditional media, with a CAGR of 29.9% between 2012 and 2016. This indicates that advertisers' focus has shifted towards digital channels due to better targeting, personalization, and overall effectiveness.

To sum up, the growth in digital media and e-commerce between 2014 and 2018 has created significant opportunities for businesses and advertisers, making it crucial for them to adapt and capitalize on the evolving trends. The boom in digital payments, the rapid growth of smartphone users, and the surge in digital advertising prove this impact. This shift in consumer behavior has allowed more players to enter the digital ecosystem, increasing retention, improving logistics efficiency, and driving customer-centric offerings.

Overall, the growth in eCommerce sales can be attributed to the increasing number of young online buyers and the advancements in technology and infrastructure that make online shopping more accessible and convenient.

On the other hand, categories with lower transaction volumes like Books, Babycare, Home Décor, Health & Personal Care, and Others also represent lower gross margin contributions. Jewellery, however, stands as an exception with a low transaction volume but a slightly higher gross margin contribution [1](image8) [4](image4). 

The two-sided business model of e-commerce relies on both supply and demand factors [5](image5). As seen in the gross margin contributions, certain product categories like Mobile, Tablets & Accessories and Fashion, Footwear & Accessories are essential for a successful e-commerce platform as they drive customer acquisition and retention, offering a wider selection to meet consumer demands and expectations [1](image4) [5](image5). 

However, to fully capitalize on these transactions, e-commerce platforms must focus on improving the shopping experience and competitive pricing without being overly reliant on discounts. Additionally, e-commerce businesses should consider integrating various electronic payment methods, such as debit and credit cards and net banking, in order to cater to the diverse needs of the Indian market [2](image2) [3](image3) [11]:

> With increasing digital payments penetration, the share of COD shipments is reducing, while there's an up tick of EMI payments and 3rd party wallets. By 2016, half of Indians will have debit cards!

In conclusion, e-commerce platforms must prioritize product categories with high transaction volumes and gross margin contributions, enhance the customer experience, and adapt to the changing dynamics of payment methods to create a robust and successful supply and demand model.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is a part of the Department of Space (DOS) in India, which is overseen by the Prime Minister and the Space Commission. ISRO has various specialized centers and facilities across the country, including space research centers, observatories, remote sensing centers, and headquarters and offices. Here's a visual representation of ISRO's organizational structure [image2](![ISRO's organizational structure within the Department of Space](image2)).

In terms of budget allocation for ISRO, we can examine the budgetary allocations for different programs related to space for the financial years 2015-2016 and 2016-2017, as represented in this bar chart [image1](![Budgetary allocations in different programs for the financial years 2015-2016 and 2016-2017](image1)):

- Space Technology: BE 2015-2016 - 4596.2, RE 2015-2016 - 4351.78, BE 2016-2017 - 5235.68
- Space Applications: BE 2015-2016 - 962.32, RE 2015-2016 - 967.63, BE 2016-2017 - 1034.39
- INSAT Operational: BE 2015-2016 - 1320.95, RE 2015-2016 - 1167.75, BE 2016-2017 - 796.1
- Space Sciences: BE 2015-2016 - 300.25, RE 2015-2016 - 297.75, BE 2016-2017 - 288.95
- Direction & Administration and Other Programmes: BE 2015-2016 - 208.47, RE 2015-2016 - 174.53, BE 2016-2017 - 154.02

The Grand Total for the entire budget, combining all categories, is:
- BE 2015-2016: 7388.19
- RE 2015-2016: 6959.44
- BE 2016-2017: 7509.14

This budget allocation covers the development and implementation of various space technology programs, including satellite communication, earth observation, launch vehicle, space science, disaster management support, sponsored research, system reliability and quality, safety, budget, and human resources development.

The Indian Space Programme, overseen by the Department of Space (DOS) and implemented primarily through ISRO, includes various centers that play crucial roles in different aspects of space research, technology development, and applications.

One such center is the Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) at Chandigarh [8, image1], which focuses on creating a robust microelectronics base in the country and enhancing capabilities in the VLSI domain [8]. The bar chart in image2 indicates the budget allocated to Space Technology, under which SCL's activities fall. The steady increase in allocations from BE 2015-2016 to BE 2016-2017 shows the growing importance of such technology development.

![Steady increase in Space Technology budget allocation, indicating the growing importance of technology development (image2)](image2)

Another vital center is the National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) at Gadanki [2, image1], which conducts atmospheric research and contributes to technology development, data archival, dissemination, assimilation, and modeling [2]. The Atmospheric Structure and Dynamics Group, Cloud and Convective Systems Group, Aerosols, Radiation and Trace Gases Group, and Weather and Climate Research Group are just a few of NARL's research groups, highlighting its wide-ranging contributions to space sciences [4].

The Indian Institute of Remote Sensing (IIRS) [4, image4] is another essential component of the Indian Space Programme, primarily concerned with remote sensing applications, capacity building, and outreach activities [3]. IIRS is one of the ISRO centers under the Department of Space that plays a significant role in Earth observation applications and research [9]. The increasing budget for Space Applications from BE 2015-2016 to BE 2016-2017 in image2 highlights the growing emphasis on such Earth observation applications.

![Growing Space Applications budget allocation reflects the increasing importance of Earth observation (image2)](image2)

In conclusion, various centers under the Indian Space Programme, such as SCL, NARL, and IIRS, play significant roles in different aspects of space research, technology development, and applications. The budget allocations in image2 demonstrate the increasing importance of these centers and their respective focus areas over the years.

[Here](image1) is the map of India highlighting various locations associated with the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) and related departments.
[Here](image2) is a bar chart that represents budgetary allocations in different programs related to space for the financial years 2015-2016 and 2016-2017.
[Here](image4) is a large, multi-story building labeled as the "IIRS Main Building," which is an institutional or governmental building, possibly related to research or education.

The roles and significance of different centers under the Indian Space Programme are crucial for the development and application of space science and technology in the country, with their budget allocation reflecting their importance in space technology, space applications, Earth observation, and atmospheric research.

The **National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL)** is located at Gadanki near Tirupati, and is an autonomous society supported by the Department of Space (DOS) [[3](image3)]. NARL's primary function is atmospheric research, with a vision to predict the behavior of the Earth's atmosphere through observations and modeling [[3](image3)]. The facility's upgraded Wafer Fabrication Lab includes an $8"$ CMOS Wafer Fabrication Line, which is used for production activities [[4](image4)].

![An autonomous society supported by DOS for atmospheric research](image3)

NARL's commitment to technology development, observations, data archival, dissemination, assimilation, and modeling supports its mission [[3](image3)]. An example of this is the MST Radar facility at NARL, which is used for atmospheric or meteorological research [[2](image2)].

The **Semiconductor Laboratory (SCL)** is located at Chandigarh and an Autonomous Body under the Department of Space [[7](image7)]. SCL's primary function is creating a strong microelectronics base in the country and enhancing capabilities in the VLSI domain [[7](image7)]. The facility's cleanroom environment supports this function, as it is used for the design, development, fabrication, assembly, testing, and reliability assurance of CMOS and MEMS devices [[3](image3)].

![A cleanroom environment for microfabrication and semiconductor industries](image3)

SCL's focus on the design, development, fabrication, assembly, testing, and reliability assurance of CMOS and MEMS devices helps it achieve its mission [[7](image7)].

Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat are three of the largest telecommunications operators in Indonesia. When comparing these companies, one point of interest is their number of subscribers and data users over the years.

Telkomsel has the highest number of subscribers and data users among the three. Based on image6, as of the latest available data, Telkomsel has approximately 132.7 million subscribers and 60.5 million data users. This makes it the leading telecommunications company in Indonesia in terms of subscriber count.

XL follows Telkomsel with the second-highest number of subscribers and data users. According to the same image, XL has around 68.5 million subscribers and 37.5 million data users. This places XL as the second largest telecommunications operator in Indonesia, both in terms of subscribers and data users.

Indosat holds the third position in this comparison. The company has approximately 59.7 million subscribers and 29 million data users as per image6.

To provide a more comprehensive comparison, one could look at the trends of subscribers and data users for Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat over the years. However, based on the data provided in the question, only the most recent numbers are available.

Based on the information provided, we can observe a few key points about Telkomsel's subscriber base and ARPU (Average Revenue Per User) between 2013 and 2014.

In 2013, Telkomsel had a prepaid ARPU of around 34 Rp'000, according to [image5](image5). However, the exact figure for 2

Between 2013 and 2014, we can observe a decline in ARPU for both Telkomsel and XL, particularly in voice and SMS services. This is evident in image1, which shows a downward trend for Voice ARPU and SMS ARPU during the period. In 2013 and 2014, Telkomsel had 35.4 million smartphone users, while XL had 15 million smartphone users [3][image3].

The decline in ARPU might be attributed to a few factors. First, as mentioned in quotes [2] and [4], tariffs have hit rock-bottom, leading to reduced revenues, as there is no longer a price war. Moreover, the increasing use of data-based IM, VoIP, and similar services has resulted in even less usage of SMS and voice calls, further impacting the ARPU [4][7].

For smartphone users, we notice a growth in the number of users during this period [3]. As indicated in quote [9], the e-commerce industry saw rapid growth in mobile adoption during this time. This surge in mobile usage could eventually lead to an increase in Data ARPU in the latter part of the period (2015 onwards) as users consume more data for their online activities [5].

In summary, the number of smartphone users for Telkomsel and XL increased between 2013 and 2014. However, ARPU declined due to factors like reduced tariffs and the shift towards data-based communication services. The growing e-commerce sector could eventually contribute to an increase in Data ARPU in the future.

Conclusion: The number of smartphone users for Telkomsel and XL increased between 2013 and 2014, while ARPU declined due to factors like reduced tariffs and the shift towards data-based communication services. The growing e-commerce sector could eventually contribute to an increase in Data ARPU in the future.

Music consumption trends show a clear shift towards streaming, with [it quickly becoming the largest share of the business](image1) and [streaming has become the leading format](image4). This is consistent across all genres, as shown in the chart "GENRE SHARE OF TOTAL" (image8), where streaming percentages range from 6% to 26%. 

On the other hand, album sales still hold a significant share, but the trend suggests a decline. For instance, in the Rock genre, album sales make up 37%, but this is expected to decrease as streaming continues to grow. This trend is also visible in the "Total Music Volume" chart (image2), which shows a -3% decline in "Overall Albums" in 2015 compared to 2014.

In conclusion, music consumption trends show a clear shift towards streaming, with all genres reflecting this change. This suggests that the music industry is adapting to new consumer preferences, with streaming becoming the dominant form of music consumption.

![Streaming is quickly becoming the largest share of the business while album sales are declining](image1)
![Streaming has become the leading format, with album sales showing a decline](image4)
![GENRE SHARE OF TOTAL, showing the percentage distribution of music album sales, song sales, and streams across different music genres](image8)

When looking at the contribution of streams to total music activity, there is a noticeable difference between various genres and total music consumption. 

Streaming has become the leading format in the music industry, taking up **70% of the total music activity** [[2]](image2)]. This trend holds true across many genres, although there are variations in the extent to which streams influence each genre.

For example, Rock demonstrates a strong emphasis on streams, accounting for **82% of the catalog share** [[3]](image3)]. On the other hand, the Pop genre has witnessed relatively less influence, with streams making up **58% of its catalog share**. 

When considering total music consumption, streams contribute to **23% of the Rock genre's total**, **26% of R&B/Hip-Hop**, **23% of Pop**, **12% of Country**, **10% of Latin**, **6% of Dance/Electronic**, and **3% of Christian/Gospel** [[8]](image8)].

In summary, while streams make up a significant portion of total music activity, the contribution of streams to individual genres can vary considerably. The Rock genre has the greatest influence of streams, while Pop and Country have somewhat lower, but still substantial, percentages of streams. Conversely, Latin, Dance/Electronic, and Christian/Gospel genres show a much smaller proportion of streams making up their total activity.

The catalog shares of different music formats vary significantly across genres. If we look at the image1, we can see that Rock has the highest catalog share in Total Activity, Album Sales, and Song Sales, with 68%, 63%, and 68% respectively. However, when it comes to Streams, Rock drops to 82%, which is lower than its Streams share in Pop (58%) and R&B/Hip-Hop (61%). Country has the highest Streams share (70%) among all genres.

As for the albums with the highest on-demand audio stream share, the image5 can provide some insights. In the table, there are highlighted values in green indicating the highest percentages for "Song Sales Share" (48% for Maroon 5) and "On-Demand Audio Stream Share" (18% for Nicki Minaj).

In conclusion, while Rock dominates in terms of Total Activity, Album Sales, and Song Sales, it's not the leader in Streams. Country music has the highest Streams share (70%). Among albums, Maroon 5's "V" has the highest Song Sales Share (48%), and Nicki Minaj's "The Pinkprint" leads in On-Demand Audio Stream Share (18%).

![Rock dominates in Total Activity, Album Sales, Song Sales but not Streams; Country has the highest Streams share; Maroon 5's 'V' has the highest Song Sales Share; Nicki Minaj's 'The Pinkprint' leads in On-Demand Audio Stream Share](image1)

(Note: The percentages in the conclusion are based on the data presented in the provided image1 and image5.)

In 2015, music genres varied in their share of total sales and streaming formats. According to [image4](image4), Rock, R&B/Hip-Hop, Pop, Country, Latin, Dance/Electronic, and Christian/Gospel genres were compared across Album Sales %, Song Sales %, and Streams % (in green, orange, and purple, respectively) categories.

Rock held the largest share in Album Sales % (37%), while R&B/Hip-Hop dominated Streams % (26%). Pop followed closely behind R&B/Hip-Hop with a Streams % of 23% and had the highest Song Sales % (26%). Country showed the least diversification in their sales format shares: Album Sales % was 12%, Song Sales % was 11%, and Streams % was 12%.

Additionally, [image2](image2) reveals that Rock, R&B/Hip-Hop, and Pop were the three leading genres in terms of overall popularity in 2015. Rock led with a 30% share, followed by R&B/Hip-Hop (21%) and Pop (17%). Country, Latin, Dance/Electronic, Christian/Gospel trailed behind with single-digit shares.

In summary, Rock mainly dominated Album Sales % but was less visible in Streams %; R&B/Hip-Hop and Pop excelled in Streams %, with R&B/Hip-Hop taking the lead, and Pop scoring high in Song Sales % as well. Country was the least diversified genre across all formats in 2015.

Additionally, streaming has become the leading format [11] and has led to an overall growth in music consumption since 2014 [12]. This was accompanied by a decrease in album sales (-3%) between 2014 and 2015, as shown in [image1](image1). Moreover, Rock led music format sales in 2015 [6], but [image5](image5) indicates that streaming has a significant presence in every genre, even if not consistently as dominant as in R&B/Hip-Hop.

**Answer**: In 2015, Rock dominated Album Sales %, but R&B/Hip-Hop and Pop excelled in Streams %, with R&B/Hip-Hop having the largest share. Country was the least diversified genre in sales format shares. Streaming was the leading format in 2015, and its presence impacted every genre, particularly in R&B/Hip-Hop.

The distribution of music sales formats varies across different genres, with each genre having its unique preferences. In the case of Rock, it dominates Physical Albums and Digital Albums, but lags behind in Streaming Equivalent Albums (SEA). On the other hand, R&B/Hip-Hop leads in SEA and has a strong presence in Track Equivalent Albums (TEA), but is less prominent in Physical Albums. Pop, too, is mainly driven by current trends in TEA and SEA.

![Rock is driven by catalog at all formats while Pop is mainly driven by current (image3)](image3)

Streaming has become the leading format across all music [1], and this trend is particularly noticeable in genres like Latin, Dance/Electronic, and R&B/Hip-Hop, where SEA constitutes 68%, 51%, and 39% respectively [2]. This suggests that these genres rely most on streaming.

![Streaming is the highest percentage of total music activity (image2)](image2)

In summary, the distribution of music sales formats varies significantly across genres, with Rock, R&B/Hip-Hop, and Pop being the most prominent. Among these, Latin, Dance/Electronic, and R&B/Hip-Hop rely most on streaming.

The shares of music consumption formats differ significantly between the rock and R&B/hip-hop genres. In the rock genre, physical album sales and digital album sales make up a larger proportion of the total compared to R&B/hip-hop. Specifically, rock has 32% and 26% for physical and digital album sales respectively, while R&B/hip-hop has 19% and 20%. However, when it comes to streaming, R&B/hip-hop surpasses rock with 39% compared to 26%.

The system generates a response to the user's request by following a series of steps, as depicted in the proposed architecture of an end-to-end task-oriented dialogue system (image6). Initially, the user inputs a request, like "Movie for the day after tomorrow, please" (image6). This input is processed through a bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) encoder, which creates an encoding of the user's utterance (text quote [2]). This encoding, along with the system's dialogue act embedding from the previous turn (image6), is then input into an LSTM Dialogue State to update the current state.

The updated LSTM Dialogue State is then used in dialogue state tracking, where slots or variables are identified, like the "date" being set to "Thursday" (image6). This tracked state can query an external knowledge base to retrieve relevant information, resulting in a query result encoding. The policy network then determines the next system dialogue act based on the dialogue state and query results. Finally, a natural language generator processes the determined system dialogue act to generate a natural language response.

In the example given, the system response would be "System: Ok, what time do you prefer?" (image6). This process demonstrates the system's ability to create relevant, coherent responses to the user's requests in a task-oriented setting.

The SnapNTell dataset is a unique and comprehensive evaluation dataset for Visual Question Answering (VQA) tasks that focuses on entity-centric knowledge-based information [10, 1]. This is illustrated in image1, where SnapNTell is distinguished from other VQA datasets like VQA v2, GQA, and OK-VQA, which typically have freeform yes/no or choice-selection answers. In contrast, SnapNTell questions require extensive knowledge for accurate responses [10].

When comparing the SnapNTell dataset to other VQA datasets, there are significant differences in performance by baseline models, indicating that SnapNTell is particularly effective in evaluating the capabilities of different models to recognize entities and produce responses centered around these entities [12]. Image4 further highlights this, showing that SnapNTell (ours) has the highest scores across all four evaluation metrics (ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BLEURT) when compared to other methods.

In terms of features, SnapNTell excels in several aspects. As shown in image7, the dataset contains 22 categories with a total of 7,568 entities, offering more categories, unique entities, QA pairs, images, and featuring anonymity with a significantly longer average answer length compared to other datasets like ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA [7, 9].

Lastly, SnapNTell specifically emphasizes long-tail entities, addressing a significant challenge that VLLMs face, as these models tend to produce inaccurate or hallucinated responses when handling queries involving such entities [6, 10]. This focus on long-tail entities sets SnapNTell apart from other VQA datasets, making it a valuable and powerful tool for advancing research in knowledge-based VQA tasks [3, 8].

In conclusion, the SnapNTell dataset surpasses other VQA datasets in terms of categories, entities, and knowledge emphasis. It offers more categories, unique entities, QA pairs, images, and features anonymity with a significantly longer average answer length, all while specifically targeting knowledge-intensive questions related to long-tail entities [10].

![SnapNTell focuses on entity-centric knowledge-based information, offering more categories, unique entities, QA pairs, images, and featuring anonymity with a significantly longer average answer length compared to other datasets.](image7)

The carbon dioxide equivalent (CO₂e) emissions associated with training NLP models can be quite substantial when compared to everyday activities. According to [3], training a common NLP model can emit 1,924 pounds of CO₂e, which is roughly equivalent to the emissions produced by a trans-American flight between New York and San Francisco and back [5]. This demonstrates that training NLP models contributes significantly to greenhouse gas emissions.

When considering the emissions from an average human life over one year, which is around 11,023 pounds of CO₂e [5], we can see that training certain NLP models can produce emissions equivalent to or even greater than an individual's annual carbon footprint.

Additionally, the average American life over one year results in approximately 36,156 pounds of CO₂e emissions [5]. This highlights the considerable environmental impact of training NLP models, which, if unchecked, could contribute significantly to the escalating rates of natural disasters.

Lastly, the average emissions from a car, including fuel, over its lifetime reach about 126,000 pounds of CO₂e [5]. Although this figure is significantly higher than the emissions produced by training NLP models, it is essential to remember that the environmental consequences of training these models are still a concern, given the increasing reliance on them for various applications.

To put things into perspective, [4] reveals that training BERT on GPU is roughly equivalent to a trans-American flight. Training advanced models like GPT-2 or performing NAS (Neural Architecture Search) can lead to even higher emissions. It is crucial to adopt more energy-efficient practices in training NLP models and allocate energy resources wisely to minimize their environmental impact.

In conclusion, the CO₂e emissions produced by training NLP models can be comparable to, and in some cases, even greater than, everyday activities such as air travel, an average human life's annual emissions, and the average American life's annual emissions. It is essential to prioritize energy efficiency in model development to reduce the negative environmental consequences.

![CO₂e emissions from training NLP models compared to everyday activities](image3)

Different configurations of positional encodings and loss components can significantly affect Average Precision (AP) in the DETR-DC5 model for object detection. This is demonstrated in image3, which presents results for various positional encoding configurations in an encoder-decoder model. The table lists the Average Precision (AP) and Average Precision at IoU threshold 50 (AP50) scores for different spatial positional encodings in the encoder and decoder, as well as output positional encodings for the decoder output.

When spatial positional encodings are not used in the encoder, there is a significant drop in AP, as shown in the last row of the table. However, passing positional encodings in the decoder only leads to a minor AP drop compared to using them in both the encoder and decoder. The highest AP and AP50 scores, as indicated in bold in the last row, are achieved when learned spatial encodings are passed to the attentions in both the encoder and decoder.

The importance of positional encodings in the DETR-DC5 model is further emphasized by the findings in text quote [6]. When spatial positional encodings are completely removed, the model still achieves a reasonable AP, but removing them from the attentions results in a more significant drop in AP.

In conclusion, the choice of positional encoding configurations, as well as the use of positional encodings in the encoder, decoder, or both, can significantly impact the Average Precision (AP) in the DETR-DC5 model for object detection.

`![DETR-DC5 model performance with different positional encoding configurations](image3)`

When verifying claims in the SciTAB dataset, there are several common reasoning steps and challenges that arise.

One of the most prevalent reasoning types involves closed-domain knowledge. This refers to obtaining background information from the table caption or title, such as knowing that "Prod." in a table corresponds to "Productivity". This type of reasoning is used in 12.1% of the cases in the SciTAB dataset.

Another important aspect is numerical reasoning, which includes simple lookup, comparison, subtraction, division, and other arithmetic operations. These operations are used to compare values in the table and draw conclusions. For instance, in the example provided, the claim is supported because the productivity of 57.5% appears 7.5% more often than expected by random chance.

However, there are also several challenges that arise when verifying claims in the SciTAB dataset. The most common challenge is grounding errors, which account for 50% of the cases. These errors occur when there is a mismatch between the information in the table and the claim being verified.

Additionally, ambiguity errors account for 22% of the cases. These errors occur when the claim being verified is ambiguous or lacks sufficient detail, making it difficult to determine the correct answer.

Calculation errors and program errors are also common, accounting for 20% and 8% of the cases, respectively. Calculation errors occur when there are mistakes in the arithmetic operations, while program errors occur when there are bugs or issues in the programs or algorithms used to analyze the table data.

To better understand these challenges and reasoning steps, we can examine the distribution of reasoning steps involved in each claim. As shown in the image, 6% of the claims involve only 1 reasoning step, while 8% involve 2 reasoning steps. However, the majority of the claims require 3 or more reasoning steps, with 15% requiring 3 steps, 18% requiring 4 steps, and 20% requiring 5 steps. Additionally, 7% of the claims require 7 steps, 5% require 8 steps, 3% require 9 steps, 2% require 10 steps, and 1% require 11 steps.

![A distribution of reasoning steps in the SciTAB dataset, showing the percentage of claims involving different numbers of steps](image4)

Therefore, it can be concluded that when verifying claims in the SciTAB dataset, the most common reasoning steps involve closed-domain knowledge, numerical reasoning (simple lookup, comparison, subtraction, and division), and other arithmetic operations. However, there are also several challenges that arise, including grounding errors, ambiguity errors, calculation errors, and program errors. Understanding these reasoning steps and challenges is crucial for developing effective approaches to scientific fact-checking using the SciTAB dataset.

In the SciTab dataset, several reasoning functions are employed to verify claims, with their usage proportions as follows: simple lookup (20.6%), comparison (19.5%), closed-domain knowledge (12.1%), open-domain knowledge (5.3%), commonsense knowledge (5.3%), subtraction (5.3%), division (5.3%), ranking (5.3%), determining if numbers are different or the same (5.3%), addition (4.0%), maximum/minimum (3.1%), column/row name (3.1%), trend determination (2.9%), and set verification (2.9%). The distribution of these functions indicates the complexity and variety of tasks required for claim verification in the dataset.

Conversely, when 'refuted' claims are inaccurately predicted as 'supported', models often overlook the presence of negation, demonstrating a lack of numerical reasoning capabilities.

Additionally, the model tends to default to the 'NEI' (uncertain) choice when faced with complex cases that demand extensive reasoning and a deep understanding of research findings.

Looking at the types of errors contributing to the performance differences, we can examine the distribution of errors in the S CI T AB dataset. Image2 shows the reasons for refuted claims and NEI classifications. The major refuted reasons include wrong calculation results (41.7%), wrong approximation words (33.3%), and claims being partially right (10.0%). Meanwhile, the primary NEI reasons include a lack of matching evidence (33.3%), lack of open-domain knowledge (25.0%), and lack of closed-domain knowledge (15.0%).

Moreover, image3 highlights the estimated proportions of different types of errors, with grounding errors making up 50% and ambiguity errors accounting for 22%. These error types may contribute to the performance differences between the models, as InstructGPT and GPT-4 might handle grounding and ambiguity errors differently.

Lastly, it is important to note that both models perform significantly worse than human annotators. According to text quote [2], the best result achieved by an open source LLM is 63.62 for the 2-class setting and 38.05 for the 3-class setting, which are only moderately better than random guessing. A well-trained human annotator, however, can achieve 92.46 and 84.73 F1 scores in the 2-class and 3-class settings, respectively. This reinforces the challenging nature of S CI T AB and its potential to be the future benchmark for scientific fact-checking.

In conclusion, despite both InstructGPT and GPT-4 facing challenges in accurately classifying the NEI category in the zero-shot 3-class task, GPT-4 shows more confidence in its predictions, which sometimes leads to incorrect categorizations. Grounding and ambiguity errors, as well as the lack of matching evidence and open-domain knowledge, may contribute to the performance differences between these models. Human annotators, however, significantly outperform both models, pointing to the dataset's challenging nature and its potential as a future benchmark for scientific fact-checking.

Both InstructGPT and GPT-4 show difficulty in accurately predicting the NEI (Not Enough Information) class in the zero-shot 3-class setting, as revealed in their confusion matrices (image7). InstructGPT displays a pattern of "less confidence," frequently classifying supported and refuted claims as 'NEI', while GPT-4 exhibits overconfidence, incorrectly categorizing NEI claims as either supported or refuted. This difference in behavior highlights the challenge of distinguishing between refuted and NEI claims, which is inherently difficult and something human annotators struggle with as well (Jiang et al., 2020).

The lower performance in the 3-class setting compared to the 2-class setting reveals struggles in distinguishing between 'refuted' and 'NEI' claims. The inclusion of the NEI class tends to diminish the models' confidence and shift their predictions from 'supported/refuted' to 'NEI', resulting in poorer results ([6]). Furthermore, image7 shows that GPT-4 has a much higher tendency to predict Supported or Refuted when the true label is NEI, indicating a struggle to identify claims with insufficient information.

In conclusion, the main challenges faced by InstructGPT and GPT-4 in accurately classifying NEI claims in the zero-shot 3-class classification task are distinguishing between 'refuted' and 'NEI' claims and maintaining confidence in predictions where domain knowledge or the availability of information is limited.

The safety performance of Llama 2-Chat models is highly competitive when compared to other AI models. The process of Conscious Incompetence refers to the model's ability to identify missing knowledge and its role in affecting precision, recall, and F1-Score. This concept is explored in the context of retrieval analysis through an experiment that removes an increasing number of knowledge elements.

The line graph in image1, titled "Experiment Result on Conscious Incompetence," illustrates the impact of removed knowledge elements on precision, recall, and F1-Score. As more knowledge is removed, we can observe the following trends:

- **Precision** (blue line with circle markers) significantly increases, starting around 14 and reaching approximately 26. This increase in precision suggests that the model becomes more confident in its responses as more knowledge is removed, as there is less information to contradict its generated outputs.
- **Recall** (orange line with diamond markers) remains relatively stable, starting around 14 and ending slightly below 15. Despite the model's increased confidence, its ability to identify and utilize all the relevant available knowledge remains consistent, which is crucial for maintaining good recall.
- **F1-Score** (green line with triangle markers) exhibits a moderate increase, starting around 14 and ending around 18. The F1-Score is a harmonic mean of precision and recall, offering a balanced perspective on how the model is performing in the context of increased removed knowledge elements.

To further understand the consequences of the model's performance in the context of Conscious Incompetence, let's examine image2. This table (image2) displays the performance metrics of two models (possibly GPT-4 and ChatGPT) as knowledge is progressively removed. The columns "Removed," "Corr.," "Prec.," "Rec.," and "F1" likely represent the measured metrics for each model under different settings of removed knowledge elements. The rows, labelled from "0 (gold)" to "3," show the deterioration in performance as knowledge is removed. As the number of removed knowledge elements increases, there is a discernible decline in the model's performance, illustrating the challenges of Conscious Incompetence.

The image3 diagram offers visual guidance on evaluating precision and recall for generated citations, allowing us to assess the model output in the context of Conscious Incompetence.

From the experimental evidence, it can be concluded that the removal of knowledge elements adversely impacts precision, recall, and F1-Score in the context of Conscious Incompetence and retrieval analysis. Models like GPT-4 and ChatGPT experience a quantifiable drop in their performance as knowledge is removed, highlighting the significance of incorporating diverse attribution sources and addressing coverage problems in future language attribution works.

In summary, the removal of knowledge elements results in models becoming more confident in their generated outputs, as seen by an increase in precision, while their ability to effectively recall and identify all relevant knowledge remains consistent. This trade-off between confidence and recall highlights the challenges of Conscious Incompetence, manifesting in reduced precision, recall, and F1-Score as more knowledge is removed during retrieval analysis.

Conclusion: The removal of knowledge elements negatively affects precision, recall, and F1-Score in the context of Conscious Incompetence and retrieval analysis. As more knowledge is removed, there is a decline in the model's performance Pinpointing the Need for Incorporating Diverse Attribution Sources and Addressing Coverage Issues in Future Language Attribution Works.

The use of logical constraints and demonstration samples significantly affects the performance of different models on the MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets. [1](image1) shows an ablation study of ChatGPT for demonstrations and iterative retrieval, focusing on the impact of logical constraints on performance and consistency. As the number of demonstration samples increases, models with logical constraints generally perform better than those without them. This trend is consistent across both the MAVEN-ERE and CTB datasets.

Moreover, [2](image2) illustrates three methods for incorporating logical constraints into large language models (LLMs)—generative, retrieval, and pre-training. These methods enable models to derive answers more accurately based on refined logical constraints, leading to improved performance and consistency in capturing relationships between events.

[3](image3) highlights the performance of two models, Vicuna-13B-PT and Llama2-13B-PT, on the MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets given various conditions, including vanilla ICL, vanilla ICL with CoT, and CoT with logical constraints. Different configurations, such as using all logical constraints, retrieved logical constraints, and post-processing, yield better Micro-F1 scores and lower logical inconsistency percentages.

The [4](image4) case study demonstrates that pre-training techniques can increase the logical consistency of generated outputs, as shown by comparing the Llama-2-13B and Llama-2-13B-PT models.

Overall, logical constraints and demonstration samples can positively impact model performance on tasks requiring deductive reasoning and event-related information extraction. The challenge lies in obtaining relevant logic and utility constraints for LLMs, but combining methods like pre-training, generative, and retrieval-based approaches can yield improved and consistent results across various models and datasets.

Based on the provided text quotes [1], [2], [3], [5], [6], [10], [11], and image quotes image1, image3, and image7, we can compare the effectiveness of logical constraints and post-processing on reducing logical inconsistency in different LLM models across MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets.

In conclusion, logical constraints and post-processing are both effective in improving the performance and reducing logical inconsistency in different LLM models across MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets. There are several evaluation frameworks that focus on both retrieval and generation quality in Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) models. Some of these frameworks include RGB, RECALL, RAGAS, ARES, TruLens, and CRUD. 

The RGB framework targets Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality, with metrics such as Accuracy, EM (Exact Match), and R-Rate (Reappearance Rate) for aspects like Noise Robustness, Negative Rejection, Information Integration, and Counterfactual Robustness. 
![RGB evaluation framework with targets and metrics](image2)

RECALL focuses on Generation Quality, using R-Rate for Counterfactual Robustness. RAGAS, ARES, and TruLens target both Retrieval and Generation Quality, addressing Context Relevance, Faithfulness, and Answer Relevance, with unspecified metrics for RAGAS and ARES and Accuracy for TruLens.

CRUD stands out as it covers a wide range of evaluation aspects, including Creative Generation, Knowledge-intensive Question Answering, Error Correction, and Summarization, with metrics like BLEU, ROUGE-L, and BertScore. 
![CRUD evaluation framework with targets and aspects](image2)

In conclusion, various evaluation frameworks focus on both retrieval and generation quality in RAG models, using diverse metrics and aspects tailored to their specific evaluation targets. By employing these frameworks, researchers and developers can better assess the performance and robustness of RAG model outputs.

So, to answer your question directly: Several evaluation frameworks focus on both retrieval and generation quality in Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) models. These include RGB, RECALL, RAGAS, ARES, TruLens, and CRUD, with various metrics and aspects tailored to their specific evaluation targets.

When evaluating a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) model, there are several key aspects to consider. These aspects include **Context Relevance**, **Faithfulness**, **Answer Relevance**, **Noise Robustness**, **Negative Rejection**, **Information Integration**, and **Counterfactual Robustness**. Each of these aspects can be evaluated using specific metrics, which are summarized in the table below [image1].

- **Context Relevance** can be assessed using Accuracy, EM, Recall, Precision, Cosine Similarity, Hit Rate, MRR, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L.
- **Faithfulness** can be evaluated using Accuracy, EM, BLEU, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L.
- **Answer Relevance** can be assessed using Accuracy, EM, and R-Rate.
- **Noise Robustness** can be evaluated using Accuracy, Recall, and Precision.
- **Negative Rejection** can be assessed using Accuracy and EM.
- **Information Integration** can be evaluated using Accuracy, MRR, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L.
- **Counterfactual Robustness** can be evaluated using Accuracy and ROUGE/ROUGE-L.

Different evaluation frameworks focus on various subsets of these aspects and use slightly different metrics to evaluate RAG models. For example, the RGB framework focuses on Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality, evaluating Noise Robustness, Negative Rejection, Information Integration, and Counterfactual Robustness using Accuracy, EM, and other metrics [image4]. On the other hand, the RECALL framework focuses solely on Generation Quality and Counterfactual Robustness, evaluating it using the R-Rate metric [image4].

RAGAS and ARES frameworks, primarily concerned with Context Relevance, Faithfulness, and Answer Relevance, use metrics like Accuracy, Cosine Similarity, and others [image4]. TruLens, another evaluation framework, also assesses these aspects, but the specific metrics it uses are not specified [image4]. Lastly, the CRUD framework evaluates both Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality, focusing on Creative Generation, Knowledge-intensive QA, Error Correction, and Summarization using metrics such as BLEU, ROUGE-L, BertScore, and RAGQuestEval [image4].

In summary, various evaluation frameworks use different aspects and metrics to assess RAG's retrieval and generation quality. However, they all share a common goal of ensuring the model's accuracy, relevance, robustness, and faithful integration of retrieved information.

The RGB evaluation framework focuses on Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality, assessing Noise Robustness, Negative Rejection, Information Integration, and Counterfactual Robustness. On the other hand, the CRUD evaluation framework targets Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality, specifically evaluating Creative Generation, Knowledge-intensive QA, Error Correction, and Summarization (image5, [12]).

The RGB evaluation framework uses metrics such as Accuracy, Exact Match (EM), Cosine Similarity, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L to assess Context Relevance, Faithfulness, and Answer Relevance. In comparison, the CRUD framework employs metrics like BLEU, ROUGE-L, BertScore, and RAGQuestEval to measure the quality of generated text and retrieved information in creative, knowledge-based, corrected, and summarized forms (image5, [12]).

In simpler terms, while both RGB and CRUD evaluation frameworks target Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality, RGB puts more emphasis on assessing different aspects of faithfulness and relevance, while CRUD focuses on the creative and correct generation of various NLP tasks (image5, [12]).

The evaluation frameworks RGB, RAGAS, and CRUD each have their unique targets, aspects, and quantitative metrics used in evaluation.

RGB focuses on Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality with targets such as Noise Robustness, Negative Rejection, Information Integration, and Counterfactual Robustness. The metrics used include Accuracy, EM, Recall, and Precision.

RAGAS targets Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality with aspects including Context Relevance, Faithfulness, and Answer Relevance. The metrics used are Cosine Similarity, but other metrics are unspecified.

The Advanced RAG introduces specific improvements to overcome the limitations of Naive RAG by enhancing retrieval quality through pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies [1]. It also refines its indexing techniques through a sliding window approach, fine-grained segmentation, and the incorporation of metadata [8]. In contrast, the Modular RAG offers remarkable adaptability by allowing module substitution or reconfiguration to address specific challenges [3]. This is achieved by incorporating additional specialized components like the Search module, RAG-Fusion, Memory module, Routing, Predict module, and Task Adapter module [9, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21]. As shown in image5, Modular RAG enhances flexibility by introducing various specific functional modules, facilitating non-sequential methods such as iterative retrieval and adaptive approaches, allowing for more dynamic interactions [11].

In summary, Advanced RAG improves upon Naive RAG by enhancing retrieval quality and refining indexing techniques, while Modular RAG further expands the capabilities of RAG with its adaptable and specialized components.

Direct Answer: The Advanced RAG enhances retrieval quality and refines indexing techniques, while Modular RAG offers remarkable adaptability by allowing module substitution or reconfiguration with additional specialized components to address specific challenges and improve retrieval quality.

The Naive, Advanced, and Modular RAG frameworks each have distinct approaches to handling document retrieval and query processing.

The Naive RAG follows a traditional process that includes indexing, retrieval, and generation, which can be characterized as a "Retrieve-Read" framework [7]. This approach is straightforward, but it may not always provide the most precise or contextually relevant responses.

The Advanced RAG introduces specific improvements to overcome the limitations of Naive RAG, focusing on enhancing retrieval quality. It employs pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies, refines indexing techniques, and incorporates optimization methods to streamline the retrieval process [8]. These enhancements aim to provide more accurate and contextually relevant responses than the Naive RAG.

The Modular RAG architecture takes a step further by offering enhanced adaptability and versatility. It incorporates diverse strategies for improving its components, such as adding a search module for similarity searches and refining the retriever through fine-tuning. Innovations like restructured RAG modules [13] and rearranged RAG pipelines [14] have been introduced to tackle specific challenges. This modular approach supports both sequential processing and integrated end-to-end training across its components [11].

To summarize, while the Naive RAG follows a traditional "Retrieve-Read" framework, the Advanced RAG introduces improvements to enhance retrieval quality, and the Modular RAG offers enhanced adaptability and versatility by incorporating various strategies and modules to handle document retrieval and query processing more effectively.

The RAR (LLaVA1.5) model exhibits strong performance in both fine-grained visual recognition and zero-shot object recognition tasks.

In fine-grained visual recognition, the RAR (LLaVA1.5) model surpasses other methods in the 1-shot to 16-shot experiments by an average of 6.7% [3]. In comparison to the CLIP+KNN method, the RAR (LLaVA1.5) model demonstrates consistent improvement in various shot settings, as shown in image2. Additionally, the RAR (LLaVA1.5) model significantly outperforms GPT-4V in terms of accuracy across eleven datasets [5].

Regarding zero-shot object recognition, the RAR (LLaVA1.5) model reranks class names correctly using multi-label learning models (MLLMs) as shown in image7. The reranking process helps the model accurately select the correct class names for the objects in the provided images.

In summary, the RAR (LLaVA1.5) model is a highly capable model in both fine-grained visual recognition and zero-shot object recognition tasks, with consistent improvements over other methods in various experiments. The table in image2 highlights the fine-grained visual recognition performance, while image7 demonstrates the zero-shot object recognition capabilities of the RAR (LLaVA1.5) model.

> The RAR (LLaVA1.5) model has robust performance in both fine-grained visual recognition and zero-shot object recognition tasks, consistently outperforming other methods.

The RAR (Retrieving and Ranking) models, when applied to zero-shot object recognition, show significant improvements over the baseline models. These improvements are particularly notable for rare categories. For example, as shown in [5], the RAR method achieves a peak performance on APr (Average Precision for rare classes), surpassing the CLIP model by up to 19.6 percentage points. This indicates a substantial advantage of the RAR method in handling rare categories, demonstrating the method's enhanced ability to discriminate among infrequently encountered objects.

The RAR's integration with MLLMs (Multimodal Large Language Models) plays a crucial role in this enhancement. The retrieving and reranking mechanism effectively pools relevant information from the external memory, providing the MLLMs with a richer context for rare class identification. This mechanism ensures that even lesser-represented classes receive adequate attention during the classification process, addressing one of the significant challenges in long-tailed distribution datasets.

To visualize these improvements, consider the following image:

![The RAR models show significant improvements in zero-shot object recognition, particularly for rare categories, over the baseline models.](image8)

This image is from the LVIS validation set, where the CLIP & K-NN approach provides an extensive list of object predictions, but the most accurate label might not always emerge as the top-1 choice. The incorporation of MLLMs in the RAR significantly streamlines the prediction process, yielding more precise and relevant object labels, demonstrating the RAR's ability to meet the needs of fine-grained and large vocabulary recognition.

The multimodal retriever system processes and ranks objects for recognition in detection datasets by first pre-processing the images in the dataset. This includes cropping the image regions based on proposal bounding box coordinates and resizing them to a fixed proportion. A blurring technique is then employed on the non-target areas surrounding the objects of interest to direct the model's focus towards the relevant objects. These pre-processed images are then used to create and store multimodal embeddings in a memory bank.

Upon receiving an input image, the system encodes it into embeddings and navigates through the memory index to identify the top-k related images. The top-k retrieved results serve as a preliminary filter, narrowing down the possibilities to those most likely relevant based on historical data and the semantic closeness of stored labels to the image content.

The retrieved category labels alongside the image embedding are then integrated and sent to the MLLMs through a ranking prompt. The MLLMs, combining the internal knowledge and the retrieved information, make the final prediction of the image category. This proposed inference process, using both the retrieval results from the memory bank and subsequent ranking by the MLLM, ensures a more accurate and contextually aware classification prediction.

![The multimodal retriever system processes and ranks objects for recognition in detection datasets](image5)

In summary, the multimodal retriever system processes and ranks objects for recognition in detection datasets by pre-processing the images, creating and storing multimodal embeddings, retrieving the top-k related images, and using MLLMs to make the final prediction.

When comparing the error analysis results for Step-Back + RAG between TimeQA and StrategyQA [10, 11], we can observe that Step-Back + RAG is able to fix a significant number of errors on both datasets while introducing a relatively low percentage of new errors.

For TimeQA [10]:
- Step-Back + RAG fixes 39.9% of the baseline's wrong predictions.
- Step-Back + RAG introduces 5.6% of new errors.

For StrategyQA [11]:
- Step-Back + RAG fixes 15.4% of the baseline's wrong predictions.
- Step-Back + RAG introduces 4.4% of new errors.

These results indicate thatStep-Back + RAG is more effective at correcting errors in TimeQA than in StrategyQA, which could be due to the nature of the datasets and their specific error patterns [9, 12]. However, Step-Back + RAG also introduces a higher percentage of new errors in TimeQA compared to StrategyQA.

Let's analyze the data distribution and task types for each dataset [6, 8]:

- **TimeQA** contains 5226 test examples. The questions cover a wide range of topics and require understanding the timeline of events and their implications.
- **StrategyQA** contains 229 dev examples. This dataset explores the causes and effects of various historical and hypothetical events.

Considering these characteristics and the error analysis results, we can conclude that Step-Back + RAG has a more significant impact on the TimeQA dataset, despite introducing more new errors compared to StrategyQA. The differences in performance could be attributed to the size and nature of the datasets as well as the specific error sources present in each dataset [10, 11, 12].

Overall, Step-Back + RAG proves to be a helpful approach for improving the accuracy of model predictions on both TimeQA and StrategyQA by addressing the original question after performing abstraction. Nonetheless, it is important to consider the dataset specifics and task types when interpreting error analysis results and evaluating the effectiveness of the method.

![Error Analysis for Step-Back + RAG on TimeQA and StrategyQA](image10%20%5BStep-Back%20fixes%2039.9%%20errors%20in%20TimeQA%5D%2C%20image11%20%5BStep-Back%20fixes%2015.4%%20errors%20in%20StrategyQA%5D)

The 'Step-Back' prompting method is a few-shot prompting approach that has been shown to significantly improve model performance across a range of tasks, including TimeQA and SituatedQA, without requiring updates to any model parameters [1][8][11]. It is inspired by the idea that taking a step back and looking at a broader level helps humans perform complex tasks.

In terms of error analysis, 'Step-Back' has been shown to fix 39.9% of errors made by the baseline models, while introducing only 6.3% new errors when combined with RAG [6]. The most common errors made by 'Step-Back' are reasoning errors, as shown in Figure 6 [7].

When compared to other methods on various benchmarks, 'Step-Back' shows strong performance. On TimeQA, 'Step-Back' + RAG achieves an accuracy of 68.7%, outperforming the baseline models of GPT-4 and PaLM-2L (which achieved 45.6% and 41.5%, respectively) [3]. The 'Step-Back' method also demonstrates robust performance against the number of exemplars used in demonstration [5].

On Knowledge QA tasks, 'Step-Back' prompting results in significant performance improvements, as shown in Table 8 [8]. The method is also effective on SituatedQA, with a moderate quality gain from 54.3% to 61% when using the best method of Step-Back + RAG [10].

Overall, the 'Step-Back' prompting method compares favorably to other methods in terms of error analysis and task performance across different benchmarks [1][3][6][8][10][11].

The importance of categorization and entity popularity in search engines and VQA tasks is analyzed and demonstrated using the SnapNTell dataset, the ViQuAE model, and the Encyclopedic VQA model [1, 2, 5-7]. The SnapNTell dataset encompasses a wide range of categorized entities, with each entity explicitly named in answers, allowing for a thorough analysis of entity-specific knowledge. The dataset includes 10 images and 10 knowledge-intensive QA pairs for each entity, addressing the challenges of long-tail entities and hallucinations [5]. Retrieval augmentation has been proven effective in improving performance across various entity types, particularly for torso-to-tail entities [6].
